block.p: From 13 to 50 American Institute of Graphic Arts, 164 Fifth Avenue (22nd Street); (212) 807-1990.

''Stripes and Stars: A Visual History of an American Icon,'' an exhibition of more than 200 flags and objects using the flag in their design, opens today and continues through Aug. 25. The items, from the 2,500-piece Old Glory collection belonging to Kit Hinrichs, a graphic designer, include quilts, sneakers, cans, toys, textiles, clothing, paintings, prints and collages. Open Monday through Friday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. No charge.

Garden Walks in Brooklyn
Rockwell Place Garden, corner of Flatbush and Lafayette Avenues, Brooklyn; (212) 352-9330.

On Saturday from 10 a.m. to 2:30 p.m., a guided tour will be given to a dozen community gardens in Fort Greene, Boerum Hill, Park Slope and Prospect Heights. The sites will include a garden with terraced areas for growing vegetables set around an oval and another that mixes perennial beds and boxes for growing vegetables. No charge.
New York Canvas
New-York Historical Society, Central Park West at 77th Street; (212) 873-3400.

An exhibition of 30 paintings of interiors and street scenes in Manhattan, painted between 1900 and 1999, starts tomorrow and runs through Aug. 27. Scenes include the Brooklyn Bridge, the Empire State Building, the railroad yards on the West Side and Canal Street in Chinatown. Open Tuesday through Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Suggested donation is $5; children and those 65 and older, $3.
Tropics in the Bronx
New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx; (718) 817-8700.

''The Exotic Courtyard Garden,'' an exhibition of tropical plants and trees, including cannas, bamboo, Angel's Trumpet and palms, starts on Saturday in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory and continues through Sept. 24. Garden and conservatory are open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to grounds, conservatory and children's garden is $10; students, those 65 and older, $7.50; children, 2 to 12, $4.50. Grounds admission only, $3; students, those 65 and older, $2; children, 2 to 12, $1; no charge on Wednesdays, and on Saturdays from 10 a.m. to noon.
Summer Crafts
Craft Students League at the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue, at 53rd Street; (212) 735-9731.

Summer sessions of craft classes and one-day workshops will start on July 8 with the use of color in jewelry design (also on July 15). A six-session class on painted finishes begins on July 11; a 10-session class on making wooden boxes starts on July 10, and a one-day workshop on basic paper making is set for July 29. Reservations are required. Fees are $85 to $345. A schedule is available by calling.
Chairs for the Outdoors
New York School of Interior Design, 170 East 70th Street; (212) 472-1500, ext. 194.

Chairs, benches and lounge chairs designed by the Munder-Skiles company are on display with drawings, historic furniture and photographs through Aug. 3. The designs include chairs based on a Thomas Jefferson 1801 bench for Monticello and tree planters inspired by those at George Washington's Mount Vernon estate. Open Monday through Thursday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (closed July 3 and 4). No charge.
Inside and Out
Old Westbury Gardens, 71 Old Westbury Road between the L.I.E. and Jericho Turnpike; (516) 333-0048.

Among the guided tours and talks set for July are a lecture, on Sunday, on hybrid day lilies that grow well on Long Island; a look at the antique furniture decorating Westbury House, a Charles II-style mansion built in 1906 (July 8); the house's carved ceilings, moldings and pediments (July 15); and growing drought-tolerant plants (July 23). Programs start at 2 p.m. and are free with admission. Open Wednesday through Monday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the house and gardens is $10; those 62 and older, $8; children 6 to 12, $6. Grounds admission only is $8; those 62 and older, $6; children 6 to 12, $3.
